data.title: Living in Jávea: one of the most charming coastal towns in Alicante
data.meta_description: Jávea is among the beautiful towns of Alicante that must be visited and is located in the north of the province, in the Marina Alta region. It is one of the most well known coastal towns and has some of most famous beaches in Spain.
data.text:
Jávea is among the beautiful towns of Alicante that must be visited and is located in the north of the province, in the Marina Alta region. It is one of the most well known coastal towns and has some of most famous beaches in Spain. In addition, its two sea caves that can be visited by kayak or hiking routes through the Montgó Natural Park stand out, which will delight the kids.

Things to do in Jávea ​​​​​​​

What to see

Appeal for its nature: Jávea can be found in Valencia province, which houses 159 of the blue flag beaches, and gems like Granadella (ranked sixth in the most beautiful beaches in the nation) or Cala de la Barraca to take a dip in. There are 25km of coastline to try.

Appeal for its culture: Worth seeing in its Old Town are the essential Church of San Bartolomé, the Ethnological Museum, the Municipal Market and the Jávea Town Hall. Jávea is an upmarket place to live, which guarantees that it is cared for in landscaping, is clean and has colonial facades and monuments which maintain their great beauty.

Activities

For Children: Spanish families chose to have a second home in Jávea because there's a broad range of beach caves to explore and lot of rocky surface to climb with the help of guides. For instance, there are trails to see the sleeping elephant formation from the top of Montgo Mountain or following the other 45km of trails in the surrounding area. They also love the rare reptiles and birds found on site, only here in Jávea.

For adults: There are custom scuba-diving expeditions to caves and grouper migration areas. One can also go sailing or kayaking, cycling the maritime routes, or make use of the 13 golf courses to decompress.

Summer festivals: The most beloved by the Spaniards are the three phenomenal celebrations that take place each year - Our Lady of Loreto, Fogueres of San Juan and Moros y Cristianos; all of which entail a lot of wine, fire spectacles and local craftsmanship.

Living in Jávea​​​​​​​

Hub for Celebrities

Jávea has a reputation for being quite 'posh', with its vast Golf Club and exclusive restaurants of the best quality in Costa Blanca, such as La Bambula and BonAmb. Known informally as the 'Mónaco of Spain', its why famous people keep returning, like actors Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones, Marta Ortega the heiress to the Inditex empire, tennis legend David Ferrer and Latin music heartthrob Julio Iglesias all frequent this luxurious coast. They live in large homes decked with deep pools and stone tosca arches. Jávea has the highest priced average for properties of all the municipalities of Spain according to the UVE reports. Jávea is so popular because it's very attractive and priotitises creature comfort above all.

Look for your Next Property in Jávea

Jávea won't have the holiday roster that cities like Benidorm will, so most rely on renting or making a bigger investment and purchasing a home. Jávea is a sunny paradise, don't wait to check out our listings here:

Property for sale in Jávea

Long-term rentals in Jávea

Holiday rentals in Jávea​​​​​​​

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ's)

What is the coldest month in Jávea?

The coldest month here is January at 13°C on a winter's day average. The wettest season starts in October, and the hottest and longest days are in July and August. To enjoy aquatic activities, it's important to note that the sea temperature stays warmest from June to October, with the lowest temperatures being 21°C and highest 26°C.

Which is better, Dénia or Jávea?

Dénia is more upbeat: The amenities are endless and the general attitude is one of going out and mingling. Friends and family gather here from all over Spain at certain points of the year, they come ready to spend that time in reverie, which is the same with Jávea but in a much more tranquil and close-nit way.

Cost of living is higher in Dénia: In the cost of a property, monthly utilities, supermarket food and in outings like the cinema.

The average price for sale in Denia is €2,479/m2, and for rent €9.6/m2.

Find flats and houses for sale in Denia and rental properties. For getaway options, look at the holiday rental alternatives.

Dénia is better connected: By sea and through the line 9 tram to other coastal towns. Regardless, they are only a 16km drive away from each other.

The Spanish essence of Jávea is more pronounced: Neighbouring cities like Calpe or Benidorm lose on this because they have more high-rises and tourist-focused attractions. Dénia maintains this also but at less luxurious foreign standards, with its larger community of Spanish locals and catholic festivities.

How far is Alicante from Jávea?

It is easiest to access by plane however, being equidistant to Valencia and Alicante and receiving cheap flights from Europe and North Africa's largest cities. The Denibus is the most popular for in-city travel, leaving longer tram rides to the rest of Costa Blanca at 10€ to 15€ a journey. Check out our complete list of the most beautiful villages in Alicante that you should visit.

How safe is Jávea?
